elements.title: Regulatory Requirements for Acquiring Control and Dividend Distributions

data.value: State insurance laws require obtaining approval from the insurance commissioner before acquiring control of an insurer.
Control is presumed if any person owns, controls, or holds proxies representing 10% or more of voting securities of the insurer (or any parent entity).
Factors include the applicant’s experience, competence, financial strength, board integrity, management plans, and potential anti-competitive effects.
Acquirers of insurers licensed in a jurisdiction but not domiciled there may need to file prior to an acquisition if market shares overlap.
Insurance subsidiaries must notify the commissioner of dividends or distributions and obtain affirmative approval before payment, with specific notice periods.

An extraordinary dividend is defined as one that, with other distributions in the last 12 months, exceeds the greater of 10% of the insurer's statutory surplus or its prior year’s statutory net income.
The NAIC provides model laws and accounting guidance which, when adopted by states, impact statutory capital and surplus. Changes to these models can affect regulatory assessments.
Requires regular, at least annual, assessments of risk management and solvency by insurance holding companies, with results reported confidentially to the lead state commissioner.

elements.title: Board Nomination and Governance Provisions

data.value: The agreement states that it is in the best interests of the Company for the Company’s Chief Executive Officer to serve as a director on the Company Board.

The Parties agree to take reasonable action to secure necessary approvals from the Company Board and its Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee to include the CEO and additional nominees in the slate proposed to the Stockholders.

If the Board size is changed with Genworth's prior written approval, Genworth can designate a proportional number of additional persons to be nominated to the Company Board, and the Company must act to accommodate these nominations.

Vacancies from the death, resignation, or removal of a Genworth Designee must be filled by another Genworth Designee. In cases where a nominee is deemed unqualified, Genworth may select a replacement.

elements.title: Board Governance Provisions and Nomination Rights

data.value: Genworth Designees are not required to qualify as independent directors under SEC or Nasdaq rules unless necessary for board or committee service following the loss of 'controlled company' status.
When Genworth beneficially owns at least 10% of the outstanding Company Common Stock, the Company must notify Genworth of the expected mailing date of proxy materials.
The notice must be provided at least 60 days prior to the mailing date (or a shorter period if consented by Genworth) to allow Genworth Designees to be included.
Genworth is given a reasonable opportunity to review and provide comments on any portion of the proxy materials related to Genworth Designees or associated rights and obligations.
In case of opposition to a Genworth Designee, the Company must notify Genworth sufficiently in advance, allowing Genworth 10 business days to propose a replacement.
If Genworth loses its requisite nomination rights, it must use its best efforts to secure the prompt resignation of the affected Genworth Designees.
The Company must not increase the number of directors on the Board without Genworth’s prior written consent.
Until the Trigger Date, the Company may use certain 'controlled company' exceptions to Nasdaq's corporate governance standards for specified committees.
The Company's Charter and Amended and Restated Bylaws must accommodate and not conflict with the rights and obligations set forth in the Agreement.

elements.title: Положения о назначении представителей Genworth в комитеты совета директоров

data.value: Genworth имеет право по своему усмотрению назначать не менее двух представителей (Genworth Designees) в Совете директоров для участия в Комитете по компенсациям и, в дальнейшем, по одному представителю на каждый из других комитетов (Audit, Nominating and Corporate Governance, Risk и др.), за исключением Independent Capital Committee.

Права Genworth реализуются до наступления Trigger Date и до тех пор, пока доля владения Genworth в обыкновенных акциях компании превышает 30%. При изменении состава комитетов с предварительного согласия Genworth, компании необходимо обеспечить пропорциональное назначение дополнительных представителей.

Представитель Genworth в Комитете по аудиту должен быть независимым директором, соответствующим всем требованиям Nasdaq и SEC. При утрате статуса 'контролируемой компании' аналогичные требования применяются также для представителей в Комитете по компенсациям и Комитете по номинированию и корпоративному управлению.

data.value: During 2022 and 2021, RSUs were issued to employees with average restriction periods of 3 years and weighted average fair values of $22.18 (2022) and $19.02 (2021). Each grant was measured at the fair value of the Company’s Class A Common Stock on the grant date.

PSUs granted in 2022 have a three-year measurement period from January 1, 2022 through December 31, 2024. Their performance is evaluated based on Enact’s consolidated book value per share growth over that period.

Dividend equivalent shares were issued to holders of RSU, PSU, and DSU awards in connection with cash dividends paid in 2022 and Q4 2021; future dividend declarations are at the discretion of the Board of Directors.

The summary table details various transactions (Granted, Dividend equivalents, Exercised, Terminated) across multiple award types. data.value: This document governs the performance stock unit (PSU) award under the Enact Holdings, Inc. 2021 Omnibus Incentive Plan.
2021 Omnibus Incentive Plan
Performance Stock Units (PSUs) are granted to the participant, vesting based on continued service and achievement of Performance Goals.
Vesting occurs upon certification of performance achievements, with vested PSUs converting to Shares or equivalent cash value.
Each vested PSU entitles the participant to one share of Company common stock with $0.01 par value, or cash determined at the discretion of the Compensation Committee.
The number of PSUs earned may range from 0% to 200% of the Target Award based on performance against defined Performance Goals and the Performance Period outlined in Exhibit A.

elements.title: Insurance Claims Process and IT Infrastructure Investment

data.value: Payment is made only for covered expenses; any reduction relative to the claim notice is considered a curtailment. Coverage may be rescinded in cases of fraudulent misrepresentation, materially inaccurate information, or violation of underwriting guidelines.
If an insured appeals a decision, steps are taken to reinstate coverage and rectify the issue. Failing agreement, the insured may pursue arbitration or litigation under policy terms.
Agreements with policyholders can accelerate claim payments, resulting in cancellation of mortgage insurance and discharging further liability on the affected loans.

Significant investments are made in technology to drive operational excellence, enhance customer experience, and support business objectives. This includes automating claims, approving insurance applications, and reconciling premium remittance.

Investments include a proprietary underwriting platform, lender and servicer integration capabilities, a proprietary risk modeling platform, a business rules engine, management and portfolio reporting capabilities, and an award-winning rate quote and ordering website. Ongoing upgrades aim to improve productivity and system integration.

elements.title: Our Products and Services

data.value: There are two types of private mortgage insurance: primary and pool. Primary mortgage insurance protects individual loans at specified coverage percentages and can be delivered on a loan-by-loan or aggregated basis. Pool mortgage insurance covers a finite set of individual loans identified by the pool policy.
Premiums are calculated as a percentage of the original principal balance and may be paid monthly, as a single upfront payment, annually in advance, or through a split payment method.

Mortgage insurance coverage may generally not be terminated except due to non-payment of premiums or material policy violations. Cancellation options depend on borrower or lender actions, subject to GSE guidelines and state regulations based on loan-to-value ratios.
The typical risk across policies is approximately 25% of the underlying primary insurance in-force, varying between 6% and 35% from policy to policy.

elements.title: Overview of Customers, Sales & Marketing and New Mortgage Insurance Policy Launch

data.value: Approximately 1,800 mortgage lenders across the United States; diversified by size, type, and geography, including large money center banks, non-bank lenders, and community banks.
Largest customer accounted for 18% of total NIW in 2022; top five customers generated 30% of NIW in 2022; individual customers contributed 14% in 2021 and 12% in 2020.
Dedicated sales force, digital marketing program, strategic partnerships, and consulting services to enhance customer relationships and brand awareness.
In 2019, launched a separate mortgage insurance policy underwritten by wholly owned subsidiary EMIC-NC, offering flexibility and strategic optionality.
Long-standing relationships with customers’ technology organizations and platforms; quick customization of loan delivery solutions.

elements.title: Persistency Rate and Business Mix Analysis

data.value: Persistency rate is defined as the percentage of IIF that remains insured after accounting for annualized cancellations.

Higher persistency rates lead to increased premium collections from monthly policies over time, whereas lower persistency benefits the profitability of single premium policies due to accelerated premium earning at cancellation.

The text discusses the impact of rising interest rates in 2022, which increased persistency, and details a table of weighted average mortgage interest rates by year (e.g., 5.70% for 2008 and prior, 4.88% for 2022, with a total portfolio average of 3.84%).

Improved credit quality is noted due to enhanced analytics, stronger loan origination controls, and regulatory implementation (QM Rule), leading to higher average FICO scores in the private mortgage insurance market.

Present value of expected cash flows is compared to the amortized cost of the security; if lower, the difference is recorded as credit loss and non-credit other-than-temporary impairment.
For certain hybrid securities classified as fixed maturity, the impairment model depends on evidence of credit deterioration, potentially invoking the equity securities impairment model.
Other-than-temporary impairments are measured as the difference between the security's amortized cost and its fair value, with a maximum reasonable period of 15 months for recovery assessment.
Investments where significant influence is exerted are accounted for using the equity method unless the fair value option is elected; non-material investments are recorded in other assets and income.
Assets and liabilities are classified into Level 1, Level 2, and Level 3 based on the observability of inputs used in valuation.

elements.title: Analysis of Dividend Strategies and Regulatory Requirements

data.value: Regulators are estimated to require a minimum policyholder surplus of approximately $300 million, which could limit future dividends.
A statutory accounting requirement mandates establishing a contingency reserve of at least 50% of net earned premiums annually for ten years that is later released into policyholder surplus.
Dividend strategies are evaluated based on both prior year statutory net income and estimated U.S. GAAP net income, including the dividend payout ratio relative to actual income.
EMICO completed distributions of approximately $242 million in April and October of 2022 to support its cash dividend capability.
The credit agreement imposes restrictions on cash dividend payments, including pro forma financial covenant compliance and timing rules.

The credit agreement requires maintenance of specific financial covenants such as a minimum consolidated net worth, adjusted capital levels, a maximum debt-to-total capitalization ratio, and minimum liquidity of $25 million.
Considerations include compliance with PMIERs and statutory RTC ratios (not to exceed 25:1) as set by the NCDOI, affecting dividend strategies.

elements.title: Capital Structure Changes – IPO and Share Exchange with Genworth Holdings

data.value: Genworth Holdings exchanged 100 shares of common stock for 162,840,000 newly issued shares of common stock of EHI.
On September 15, 2021, 13,310,400 shares of common stock were issued and sold at an IPO price of $19.00 per share.
14,655,600 common shares were sold in a concurrent private sale at $17.86 per share, which was the IPO price less the underwriting discount.
Underwriters were granted a 30-day option to purchase up to 1,996,560 additional common shares at the IPO price; the option was fully exercised on September 16, 2021.
The IPO, Private Sale, and Over-Allotment Option closed on September 20, 2021, with Genworth Holdings retaining all net proceeds.
The majority of business is operated through EMICO (formerly Genworth Mortgage Insurance Corporation, renamed effective February 7, 2022).
The company aims to differentiate itself, maintain strong capital levels, optimize cost of capital, and deliver attractive risk-adjusted returns.

elements.title: Capital Requirements and Risk of Inadequate Capital

data.value: There is a risk of being unable to maintain or increase the capital needed in a timely manner through various means including improved performance, CRT transactions, or securities offerings.
Additional capital may be required to support growth, meet regulatory or GSE requirements, satisfy rating agency criteria, repay debt, and manage unexpected cash flow obligations.

As of December 31, 2022, available assets were $5,206 million against $3,156 million net required assets, with a sufficiency ratio of 165% (i.e. $2,050 million above requirements) compared to December 31, 2021 figures.

The company may need to execute future capital transactions, including additional CRT transactions, which are used to transfer risks and meet regulatory capital measurements. However, the success of these transactions depends on market conditions and other factors.
To preserve certain tax benefits, the Parent is expected to hold at least 80% of the common stock, limiting the ability to raise capital by issuing new stock.
Failure to secure additional capital on acceptable terms could have a material adverse impact on business operations, results, and financial condition.

elements.title: U.S. Residential Mortgage Market Overview and Risk Factors

data.value: The U.S. residential mortgage market is one of the largest, comprising both primary and secondary markets. It involves a wide range of participants including mortgage banks, brokers, commercial and investment banks, savings institutions, credit unions, REITs, mortgage insurers, and government-sponsored enterprises (GSEs).

GSEs are key players in the secondary market, buying residential mortgages and guaranteeing a significant portion (around 51%) of total U.S. 1-4 family residential mortgage debt. They enforce strict eligibility criteria such as credit enhancement requirements and PMIERs.

data.key: Credit Enhancement and Private Mortgage Insurance
data.value: Private mortgage insurance plays a critical role by satisfying GSE credit enhancement requirements, especially for Low Down Payment Loans. This enables secondary market sales, enhances lending capacity and manages risk.

If entities fail to meet GSE requirements—such as credit enhancement through mortgage insurance—they risk being barred from writing new insurance on loans acquired by the GSEs. This could have a material adverse effect on business operations and financial condition.

The market is influenced by the introduction of new GSE products targeting low down payment borrowers and competitive pricing by private mortgage insurers, presenting both opportunities and risks related to market expansion.

elements.title: Risk Management, Modeling, and Customer Qualification

data.value: Transactions are facilitated via our award-winning ordering and rate quote website or integrated directly within customers’ systems to drive repeat volume.

The Risk Committee of the Board of Directors oversees the enterprise risk management policies and risk profile, covering credit, market, insurance, housing, operational, model, IT risk and others that may pose a material threat.

The proprietary risk modeling platform evaluates returns, volatility, default probability, severity of loss, prepayment, and informs risk appetite, credit policy, and underwriting strategies through both expected and stress scenario analyses.
Processes include reviewing the business and financial profiles, licensing, management experience, and adherence to underwriting guidelines to ensure quality in policy acquisition and risk selection.

elements.title: Operational Risk Management and Underwriting Guidelines

data.value: Independent quality assurance function conducts pre- and post-closing underwriting reviews of statistically significant samples from individual customers and channels. The process identifies adverse trends and informs underwriters and customers with timely feedback and training, as well as adjustments to underwriting processes and credit policy.

Regular monitoring of the mortgage insurance portfolio through stress testing and analysis of concentrations by lender, geography, and policy year to evaluate performance and identify risks to the strategic plan under adverse economic scenarios; results help refine guidelines and pricing strategies.

A robust business continuity program led by a crisis management leader (reporting to the Chief Risk Officer) ensures operational resilience during business interruptions, including responses to COVID-19, through annual updates, testing via tabletop exercises, and a hybrid return-to-office staffing model.

Establishment and maintenance of comprehensive underwriting guidelines based on risk appetite. Guidelines include credit eligibility requirements and use of automated systems (e.g., Desktop Underwriter and Loan Product Advisor), with independent reviews and a proprietary mortgage insurance underwriting system investment that has significantly increased underwriter productivity.

elements.title: Details on CRT Program, Reinsurance Transactions and Risk Management

data.value: Enhances return profile through volatility protection and capital relief, integrating an 'acquire, manage and distribute' strategy.
Distributes risk via traditional reinsurance with highly rated counterparties and insurance-linked note (ILN) transactions through fully collateralized special purpose reinsurance vehicles.

Reinsurance treaties structured as excess of loss (XOL) coverage with both attachment and detachment points within PMIERs capital requirements; each treaty typically has a term of ten years or more with unilateral commutation rights under certain performance triggers.

Since 2015, a total of $4.6 billion executed across CRT transactions; includes approximately $2.8 billion of traditional XOL reinsurance covering 2009 to 2022 book years and $1.8 billion of ILN XOL coverage for 2014 to 2021 book years.
Provides an estimated $1.6 billion of PMIERs capital credit and $1.8 billion of loss coverage as of December 31, 2022.

Involves integrated loss management and claims processes, with attention to delinquencies triggered by various economic factors and structured loss mitigation efforts in coordination with servicers and GSEs.

elements.title: Risks Relating to Our Business

data.value: Failure to meet PMIERs, GSE Restrictions, and additional imposed requirements may render the company ineligible to write new insurance, adversely affecting its business, operations, and financial condition.

The amount of capital required under PMIERs is subject to interpretation, housing market performance, earnings, and achievement of required asset thresholds. Dependencies include CRT transactions and additional capital contributions.

PMIERs were amended in response to COVID-19, introducing temporary and permanent changes such as a 0.30 multiplier for non-performing loans under certain conditions and adjustments for loans under forbearance plans.

Key factors include the discretionary application of PMIERs by GSEs and FHFA, competitive pressures affecting premium rates, and the dynamic nature of asset valuations and capital adequacy requirements.

elements.title: Regulatory Reforms and Risk Factors Impacting GSEs

data.value: GSEs have been under prolonged conservatorship since September 2008 with the FHFA acting as their conservator, which controls and directs their operations.
Since 2011, numerous legislative proposals have aimed to either scale back or fundamentally reform the role of the GSEs and the United States housing finance system.
A final rule issued on December 17, 2020 (effective February 16, 2021) imposes a new capital framework on the GSEs, increasing capital requirements and reducing capital credit for CRT transactions.
Regulatory changes, including administrative reforms and potential legislative actions, could adversely affect business valuation, operations, and overall financial condition.

The FHFA has directed initiatives such as Equitable Housing Plans aimed at increasing homeownership accessibility and addressing equity issues, which may also influence the mortgage insurance industry.

elements.title: Trends and Conditions During 2022

Aggressive interest rate increases (ranging from 0.25% to 0.75% in various months) and balance sheet reductions were implemented to address inflation.
Rising mortgage rates led to a decline in mortgage origination activity and challenges in housing affordability, with home price appreciation slowing and even declining in the latter half of 2022.
The unemployment rate fell to 3.5% in December 2022, aligning with pre-COVID levels.

Forbearance plans were in place for federal government–insured mortgages with about 1.5% of active policies in forbearance, 36% of which were delinquent at year-end; new delinquency rate reached 3.8% for 2022.

elements.title: Indemnification and Litigation Management Provisions

data.value: Upon demand by the Indemnified Party, with obligation to provide reasonably satisfactory documentation detailing the basis and calculations (After-Tax Basis, Insurance Proceeds) for the indemnification or contribution payment.
Indemnity and contribution agreements remain operative regardless of investigations, knowledge of liabilities, or termination of the Agreement.
Claims not resulting from a Third-Party Claim must be asserted by written notice. The Indemnifying Party has 30 days to respond; failure to respond leads to deemed refusal.
If payment is made for a Third-Party Claim, the paying party is subrogated to the rights and claims of the Indemnified Party regarding that claim.

In actions where the Indemnifying Party is not a named defendant, parties may substitute the Indemnifying Party to manage the action, ensuring full indemnification for defense costs, judgments, settlements, interest, and penalties.
The provisions do not apply to Taxes and matters under the Tax Allocation Agreement.
The rights provided are cumulative and do not limit the Indemnified Party’s ability to pursue additional remedies as provided in the Agreement and Transaction Documents.

elements.title: Genworth Confidential Information Disclosure Restrictions

data.value: Prohibition on disclosure of Genworth Confidential Information by Company Group and its affiliates.
Allowed only to Representatives who need to know for providing services.
Same degree of care as for their own confidential information.
Public knowledge, sourced from elsewhere, or independently developed.
Entities must notify when requested to disclose Confidential Information.

elements.title: Confidentiality and Ownership Provisions

data.value: The Party receiving such request or demand agrees to take reasonable steps necessary to obtain confidential treatment.
Genworth Designees may share any non-public information about the Company received from the Company.
The Company will not sell, transfer, or dispose of its ownership in Mexican Subsidiaries without Genworth's request.
The Company shall have its own liability insurance as of the Effective Time and shall maintain such insurance continuously.
Members of the Company Group will cease to claim benefits under Genworth Insurance Arrangements after the Trigger Date.

elements.title: Insurance Arrangement Clause – Pre-Trigger Date Event and Claims Process

data.value: Defines events (claims, acts, omissions, etc.) that occurred on or prior to the Trigger Date and were reported under the Genworth Insurance Arrangement.

Upon a written request, Genworth will use commercially reasonable efforts to reduce or cancel the Company Group’s coverage, effective no earlier than 60 days post-request, with costs borne by the Company Group.
Any premium refund or credit, if received from insurers, is limited to the lesser of the refunded amount or the last charged premium.

For Pre-Trigger Date Events related to Company Liabilities, members of the Company Group may directly access and claim benefits from their occurrence-based or claims made-based insurance policies, subject to policy terms.
The Company must promptly notify Genworth’s Treasurer of any claims and cooperate in pursuing recoveries, with the Company responsible for notifying relevant insurers.

elements.title: Insurance Responsibilities and Reimbursements

data.value: All costs incurred by Genworth as a result of claims or losses.
The Company shall be liable for all deductibles, retentions, and expenses related to coverage claims.
Genworth retains exclusive control over its insurance policies and programs.
The Company must reimburse Genworth for all claim payments and associated costs.
Genworth Insurance Arrangements refer to various insurances under which the Company Group may have claims.
The Company Group must cooperate and share information to allow Genworth to manage its insurance matters.
Consent for Genworth to inform affected insurers about this Agreement.
Covers claims related to employees of the Company Group arising from occurrences prior to the Trigger Date.

elements.title: Litigation, Settlement Cooperation and Non-Compete Provisions

data.value: References to decrees and judgments by any Governmental Authority having jurisdiction over either party’s assets or organizational documents, establishing actual knowledge requirements for executive officers.
Obligations for both Genworth and the Company to cooperate in the defense and settlement of Joint Claims, including the use of commercially reasonable efforts and allocation of settlement costs.

A clause restricting Genworth and its Subsidiaries, for a period of one year from the Trigger Date, from engaging in any business competing with the Company Business in the United States and its Territories.

elements.title: ARTICLE IX DISPUTE RESOLUTION

data.value: Clause 9.1 establishes that any dispute arising in connection with the Agreement or Transaction Documents shall be resolved according to the procedures set forth, with special provisions regarding the fair market value of the Mexican Subsidiaries.
All communications during negotiations, including those related to Section 9.2 and 9.3, are deemed settlement negotiations, exempt from discovery and inadmissible in evidence.

data.key: Waiver of Damages and Jury Trial
data.value: The Parties expressly waive rights to special, indirect, incidental, punitive, consequential, exemplary damages and trial by jury.

Clause 9.2 provides that unresolved disputes at the operational level are escalated to negotiations between the senior-most executives, with defined timelines for initiating and responding to such disputes.

elements.title: Dispute Resolution: Mediation and Arbitration Procedures

data.value: If a dispute is not resolved by negotiation within 30 days of the Response, it will be submitted to mediation per CPR Mediation Procedures. The parties jointly select a mediator from the CPR Panels of Distinguished Neutrals.

If mediation fails within 30 days of mediator selection, the dispute will proceed to final and binding arbitration under the CPR Arbitration Rules. The tribunal will consist of three arbitrators, with the chair being either a former chancellor/vice chancellor of the Delaware Court of Chancery or a seasoned Delaware bar member with 10+ years experience.
The arbitration is governed by the Federal Arbitration Act (9 U.S.C. §§ 1 et seq.) and any award can be enforced in any court with jurisdiction.
The seat of arbitration will be New York, New York.

elements.title: Registration Rights Agreement - Dispute Resolution and Interim Relief Provisions

data.value: Registration Rights Agreement

The agreement stipulates that legal remedies may be insufficient, allowing for injunctive or other interim relief to prevent breaches. Interim relief may be sought both by the parties and by the arbitral tribunal.

Until the tribunal is constituted, either party may seek interim relief to preserve the status quo. Once formed, the tribunal has full authority to grant interim remedies, modify or vacate court-issued preliminary relief, and award damages for non-compliance.
The parties consent to the non-exclusive jurisdiction of any federal court in the State of New York or, if such court lacks jurisdiction, any New York state court in New York County, New York.
Each party is responsible for its own attorneys' fees and costs related to dispute resolution.
Further clauses concern corporate power and fiduciary duties, ensuring that the parties have the requisite authority to execute and perform the agreement.
